reviewText:
No, Amnesia: Memories isn't a horror game, unless playing a female protagonist who can date four different guys (and maybe N from PokÃ©mon) in a Japanese visual novel makes you break out into a cold sweat. If you keep reading, Iâ€™m going to assume you totally came here on purpose and share my strange passion for dating hot, fictional men who just canâ€™t help falling for meâ€¦with the help of a walkthrough, anyway. (Sadly, I have a rotten personality and can never self-insert.)
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=506376209

Hey look, otome fans: itâ€™s Amnesia in English on Steam! Those who have been desperately hoping for an English localization of Amnesia (and may even be veterans of the Not-So-Civil Dialoveable-Amnesiac War) will probably get this regardless of reviews. I may just be writing this for my own amusement, but hey, why not? Maybe there's someone on the fence.

...Or in a cage.

Like many of the Japanese games making their way to Steam now, Amnesia: Memories is a port. Unlike most Japanese Steam gamesâ€™ ports, however, this is Amnesiaâ€™s English debut, alongside a simultaneous Vita release. The text is all translated into English with the Japanese voice acting intact.  Fortunately, Amnesia makes a good transition from handheld to PC. Things that may seem like annoyances at firstâ€”such as being forced to left-click to progress the textâ€”are easily overcome thanks to the ability to remap keys and controller support.

The game itself looks great in 1080p as well, with easily legible text, though close-ups of characters and backgrounds suffer from minor aliasing. While the character sprites and CGs are beautiful, the backgrounds seem like stock photographs and simple line drawings with your 12-year-old cousinâ€™s favorite â€œUnicorn Diarrheaâ€ Instagram filter applied. However, my BFF (who normally has good taste) calls them â€œstylizedâ€ and â€œappropriateâ€ so it could just be my severe unicorn allergy speaking.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=506379697

Plus there are mini-games, so you get to beat your boyfriend(s) in air hockey and cackle maniacally at the first hint of their sad, sad anime boyfriend tears. Or if they beat you, Oh my god I was playing in windowed mode and I accidentally Skyped my mom when I meant to fling the puck back at you, okay, so get over yourself, Kent. Thereâ€™s also Inexplicably Violent Rock-Paper-Scissors if you prefer. (I wouldâ€™ve enjoyed seeing additional mini-games, such as Flowerpot-Dodging or Knee-the-Yandere-in-the-Groin, but I understand that this is a visual novel first and foremost.)

Amnesia is a traditional, story-focused visual novel without any stat-raising; endings are determined entirely by the series of choices you make and the parameters those choices affect. Exploring alternate realities and unraveling the mystery of your past(s) is an intriguing approach that takes precedence over the romance in most routes, and completing all five routes is necessary to reveal the full picture. I recommend seeking out the bad endings even if youâ€™re normally averse to your boyfriends hating, stabbing, or dismembering you. Then again, I probably took too much fiendish delight in finding new ways to get whatâ€™s-her-face killed.

Each route begins with already well-established relationships, though our heroine has to relearn (and hopefully remember) the exact nature of those relationships over one month. Having amnesiaâ€™s roughâ€”even when you regain consciousness and immediately find out you have a hot boyfriend. Ikkiâ€™s and Kentâ€™s routes felt like the best introduction to Amnesiaâ€™s setting and made the parameters feel especially relevant to the story. Thereâ€™s no common route at all, so the scenes and events in each guyâ€™s route are unique.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=506377418

The love interests themselves were diverse and well-written, though how appealing the routes and characters themselves are likely comes down to personal preference. I absolutely loved one route, enjoyed two very much, plodded through another because I totally already knew whodunit, and then one I fdgsffdgguyuggyhuyghgyuyuyuygugujyguyuyyujuyyhgnugngnnggyhdfrtgdhftrsgfd

Sorry, I must have gotten dizzy after recovering a repressed memory.

If youâ€™re expecting light, breezy romance, this isnâ€™t your best bet, but the feeling that youâ€™re one misstep away from a horrible fate is far stronger in some routes than others. Your adorable giant bug sidekick Orion serves as the gameâ€™s main source of comic relief and also doubles as the heroineâ€™s personality, because she apparently lost hers with her memories. Iâ€™m not a fan of â€œblank slateâ€ visual novel protagonists (probably because of my aforementioned rotten personality), and it was off-putting that the MC doesnâ€™t speak, with Orion reacting, thinking, and narrating in her stead. Luckily, Orion is the best. THE BEST.

Even taking my (exaggerated) criticisms into account, I enjoyed Amnesia very much and am thrilled that it got such a fantastic English localization from Idea Factory International. It took me 47 hours total to complete all the routes with their many endings and they were hours very well spent. I hope this is the first of many Otomate releases on Steam and Iâ€™d love for Amnesia to help prove that thereâ€™s a market for Japanese otome games here.

One last thingâ€”I forgot to make fun of the guysâ€™ outfits, which made them look like they all rolled out of a Hot Topic going-out-of-business sale circa 1995 and woke up in a giant barrel full of rejected Final Fantasy charactersâ€™ belts decades later. There, my duty is now fulfilled; it is time for me to leave you. One day (probably today), you will forget ever reading this reviewâ€¦

Note: The publisher provided each volunteer beta testerâ€”including me!â€”with a complimentary Steam copy of the game as a thank-you for testing. Beta testers werenâ€™t asked to write reviews (only bug reports), so this review is all me, baby.

reviewText:
Well, after first watching the anime for this, there's not many suprises in here for me. But, it's definitely much better than the anime. Honestly, I was kind of hoping this to be more dark - but the lighthearted touch in it isn't bad, either. If you're looking for a nice time with guys that like you, give this a try! I would guess there's around 40+ hours for you to spend in here, and I'd say it's worth the money. There's tons of pictures to unlock, minigames, extras. The art's beautiful. Not to mention, most of the usual heroine dialogue is done by Orion, so it's fully voiced - which is a breath of fresh air for me!

Orion starts out as super annoying though, but he grows on you. After two playthroughs, I'm hoping I will find a path where I can have a happy ending with that adorable spirit that's always there for you.

My complaint would be the lack of no quicksave option. Although right clicking and selecting save isn't that big of a deal, when you're searching for the right options it does make you wish there was a quicker way.

Here's to hoping they will add more japanese otome games to steam! Lets prove there's big enough of a fanbase to make it worth their money!

reviewText:
7.5/10
Estimated play time per route: 3:30 hours
Estimated full game time: 18 hours
Recommended route order: Kent, Ikki, Toma, Shin, Ukyo
Most in-depth route: Ukyo
Most lighthearted route: Kent
Darkest route: Toma

Pros:
-Edgy characters
-Stunning character art
-Smooth Japanese voice acting
-The secrets to uncover are different in each route
-Lots of unexpected, exciting endings (8 bad, 4 normal, and 4 good endings)
-No two characters are alike
-Orion. Even though he talks a bit too much, he adds a lot of needed personality to the game


Cons:
-Toma
-Romanticizes toxic relationships
-Sexist. The male protagonists treat the heroine like an item who canâ€™t fend for herself and blatantly donâ€™t respect her (Something I donâ€™t exactly fancy in general otome)
-Not enough original thoughts or insight from the heroine. I understand that the heroine is supposed to be a self-insert, but it would be nice to give her a bit of in-game personality. It felt like I was controlling a lifeless doll.
-Predictable, limited in-game choices. You can tell a bit too obviously which choice is â€œgoodâ€ and which is â€œbadâ€
-Not enough slots to save and bookmark
-Vague parameter system
-Pointless, boring mini games


This isnâ€™t the type of game Iâ€™d usually play, but after reading good reviews and finding out it was on sale for a good price, I decided to try it out. When push comes to shove, It's nothing that special. If you like otome games and gorgeous art, youâ€™ll enjoy this game. The translation has its flaws, but itâ€™s much better than most of the otome games you can buy on mobile nowadays. Itâ€™s also less expensive, since you donâ€™t have to spend $2.99 to buy each chapter. If you want to play this game but have no prior knowledge of visual novels, I would definitely recommend playing some low-key, less intense games before buying this one. I canâ€™t imagine going into this game without being familiar with anime tropes and the culture behind its gameplay, since some of the characters and places can come off as odd or unsettling. The key is to not overthink the story flaws (even though theyâ€™re in abundance) and just play it for the romance routes. If I wasnâ€™t a person who relied heavily on story growth and world building, I would have given this game a higher score. Itâ€™s not terrible, but with these types of games it's hard to impress me.

10 times better than any Voltage Inc. game, though.

reviewText:
Overall I think it's a great visual mystery novel aimed towards a female audience.  I'm still playing but it will be updated as I continue.

What I liked:

- The voice acting was very good. I loved that it was original Japanese.

- Orion is adorable
- It's an otome game which I think Steam needs more of.

What I wish was better:

- More save points! Other visual novels can have hundreds of save points. This one has only 24. Considering how many choices you have to make, I think there should be more.

Overall I would recommend if you like visual novels and you don't mind reading.

reviewText:
I am really conflicted about this game. On one hand, I think some of the plotlines are interesting, and I ended up really wrapped up in what would happen -- Shin and Ikki were my favorites by far. The character art is gorgeous, and I think that the game did an amazing job with the cliche amnesia storyline -- there's a lot you don't know but I felt like characters were suspicious when they should be and not when they shouldn't. There are things about the game that drive me crazy.

The character you play is so passive. Orion ends up being the voice for nearly everything that happens and all the recapping irritated me. Yes, I know what that character just said, Orion, I was there and there's no need to tell me yet again. I have no idea why your character would even listen to what Orion is saying given that you don't know him and he's just a random spirit that invaded your consciousness and pushed out your memories. Honestly, the game would have been a 1000% better by cutting the part Orion plays in the story in half. I never fully get why in the Toma or Shin storylines you shouldn't call the police, other than Orion tells you not to, so it ends up making no sense at all. Not to mention how you spend the games supposedly trying to recover your memories, but in the Toma storyline you find your diary and then proceed not to read it for no good reason. Why even have you find it when you did when the game doesn't allow you to read it? Orion might have forgot, but the diary is my character's person, and she definitely didn't forget.

It seems like a lot of people liked Kurt, but I really didn't, and I was so frustrated when I realized there was no way to break up with him. I would have taken a bad ending death to end their relationship, but I couldn't, and in the end, Orion ended up telling me that Kurt was a nice guy, he cared for my character, and obviously my character had feelings for him. WTF. No, no she did not. Her dialogue throughout the path made that more than clear. You see this again at the end of Shin's storyline when your character is sympathetic and apologetic to Toma who was absolutely terrible. I hate it when games force you to think a way that's completely inconsistent with how you're playing your character. There should have been an option for you to say whether you forgive him or not. (The answer is definitely not.)

I was also a little disturbed by the fact that nearly every storyline but one includes either your love interest physically manhandling you in a way that's scary or uncomfortable, initiating sexual contact without consent, or telling you that something you've said or done is going to get you sexually assaulted. Seriously, game? Whether it's a boy that likes you but you don't like them back, or someone who's sexually interested in you while you're either unsure of your interest in them or don't have any interest at all, the game makes it sound like your character has done something wrong. Also, when the women in the game are jealous, they're crazy and murderous, when the men are, it's just because they love you so much. That's not a good message to send. Jealousy isn't sexy or romantic and shouldn't be portrayed like it is. (And as much as a personally liked Ikki's character, I wish the game had addressed the fact that the members of his fan club were all essentially magically roofied by his eyes. This game had so many consent issues in it, and that's before you get to crazy Toma.)

Also, while this is definitely less important than the other issues I had in the game. I really became sick of some of the repetive background art, particularly during Kurt's storyline where you seem to walk a lot but with no dialogue the repetition is both more obvious and tedious. As negative as I'm being about the game, I didn't hate it. I think it could have been a really amazing game, and I did like playing several of the storylines. But the physical and sexual aggression we see from guys we are supposed to like was a bit too far for me. I get it in Ukyo and Toma's storylines but I hate that it pops up in everyone single one of them.

reviewText:
TL;DNR- Very great VN. 9.5/10 Would forget about life again.

Now for the long version: this is quite possibly my favorite VN that I've played to date. I should start with a disclaimer that I'm fairly unusual in that I'm a straight male who generally prefers otome VNs, but if you can get over being a virtual girl chasing after virtual boys (or rather being a virtual girl being chased by virtual boys, I suppose) then I would recommend this VN to you regardless of your preferences... assuming those preferences didn't exclude VNs themselves, I suppose.

The story is fairly simple- you're a girl who lost her memories because I spirit crashed into your noggin or something and threw them across time and space and you gotta retrieve them by talking to a bunch of cute boys in parallel worlds who knew you before you lost your memories... that's about it (well, for the most part... the final arc has quite a bit more to it, but I'm not gonna spoil). Though this fairly simple setup allows it to focus more on the characters rather than developing a convoluted plot, and it does so very well. The writing is very good, dare I say quite exceptional by most standards, I found myself genuinely laughing and crying many times, it was really quite absorbing.

If I have any criticisms though, the first one would be the character design. reviewText:
I played the Japanese version of this game way back 2013, and didn't get to finished it because of the language barier. Now 2015, it was surely surprising to see that this one got an English localization.  I bought it immediately and I was hooked! This game is not related to the horror game Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs, this is an entirely different game.

Crazy boys, gorgeous art and some mystery.You play as a heroine whom Orion (a spirit) accidentally collided into, and because of that you lost some of your memories. In a span of 1 month you need to figure out whom to trust, what happened,  and piece it out (while the people around you should not know that you have lost your memory so you wont get taken advantage of). I've never had a dull moment in the craziness of some routes. Yes crazy I tell you, like being caged or almost dead!   Best of all it's 1080p (high resolution), compared to the original small scaled handheld game.

I have to recommend Amnesia:Memories  because of what it offers: a twist of fun, sweet,  and something crazy. With regards to the difficulty in picking the right direction for a good end to happen, feel free to refer to walkthoughs. I have to say I ran into the bad end multiple times without a guide because the choices are not obvious at all. Just remember that not all choices are good, which makes it even more challenging if you play it without the walkthrough.

Want more Japanese games to be tranlated to English?Diabolik lovers, Shinobi Koi Utsusu, Hakuoki, Norn 9?
I encourage you to try and buy this game! They're testing out the western market by releasing their first localized visual novel. If this happens to be successful, we can see more visual novels in the market!

New to Visual Novels?If you're still new to visual novels, think of it as reading a goosebumps book where you can choose how the story ends by picking a dialogue. However what makes visual novels a unique experience is that, you get well known voice actors in the anime industry to voice out the characters, gorgeous art,  mini games, and a friendly fan community.

reviewText:
Amnesiaâ„¢: Memories is one of those visual novels I would read a thousand times if I just wouldn't have to deal with all those emotions again. I am that kind of person that enjoys crying while reading, smiling while nice things happen and being excited for several situations that might occur. I am very sentimental, and Amnesiaâ„¢: Memories reminded me how many emotions you can actually feel while sitting in front of your computer just reading something about a girl with amnesia that is trying to get back all of her memories.

The storyAs heroine, you get thrown into different worlds that all contain different stories. After meeting up with Orion, a friendly spirit that accidently bumped into your soul, you get to choose a world you want to start in. Every world stands in connection with one specific guy that will either act or actually be your boyfriend. Why act? Because when entering a world, you won't know anything. Starting off with amnesia after an accident, you'll meet a guy that will most likely pretend to be your boyfriend. It's your task to find out if you actually liked this guy before, or if he's just making up a quick excuse to make you do something you don't want to do.
During every walkthrough you will encounter the same people, but different faces. No one will be the same, except for a handful of persons that are trustworthy and willing to stand by your side no matter which world you're in. They won't know you met them before in another world, neither will anyone recognize that those even exist. You are on your own with a cute spirit lurking around in your head trying to help you get through the daily life you used to live before. Will you fall to those guys that are messing around with you, or will you end up with someone that truly loves you?

The boys (contains spoilers!!)I personally started in the heart world, meeting Shin first. Shin is that kind of guy that girls like because he's a bad boy you can make out with. You don't expect him to want anything serious, but honestly? Shin surely loves his girl and would do anything for her. He will stand by your side the whole time, you can trust or mistrust him and he'll still try to make it work out. If you want someone to fight for you, that's probably the right world to choose first. At least it's easy to get into it, since you'll be introduced to people that are just trying to be nice and not hating on you for things you don't remember. Shin stays by you all the time even while being busy for exams, and you won't regret trusting him on his actions.
Moving onto the diamond world and finding Toma who first showed up as the caring brother but also ended up being the culprit. In this world, he'll pretend to be your boyfriend. You don't know him so you simply believe him and end up in his hands, not being able to trust anyone but having to rely on him until you and the spirit Orion realize what's going on with this whole story Toma made up for you. Overall, depending on how your story ends, and how crazy your mind is, you'd love Toma. He's a pretty little psycho with a dirty mind as well. He seems a little bit like he's got a split personality over time, but it's nothing that wouldn't make it even more interesting to deal with.
The spade world will personally introduce you to Ikki, who has a special condition. Every girl that looks into his eyes falls in love with him, except for you. You don't fall for it which makes it get interesting. Between all of the chicks that want Ikki and the fact how dangerous they are, Ikki would do everything to make you happy. He's like Skin gone sexual, which is pretty much everything you could wish for. Except that his fan club is trying to kill you. But hey, at least you dated him for three months without remembering, right?
Last but not least, the clover world will bring you near Kent who is the opposite of all the guys listed above. He is a really smart guy, way older than you and has also been a teacher of yours. He's a master at mathematics and also a good friend of Ikki, who of course, would love to seduce you in that world as well. But you will fall for Kent and his love to you. He is trying to understand how love and relationships work, and that's the part where you come in. No matter what you demand, he will go along with it and try to make you happy. He couldn't stand seeing you crying, so he doesn't intend to let you down at any cost.
The final world will only unlock once you finished all routes, but it's worth. The joker world will finally bring you together with the guy you loved all along. Ukyo and you meet up in every world you enter, except you will never get to know him any better. He will remind you of how you met earlier, but you won't recognize it. This time, you simply get to see him day by day and having him save your life in a world that is trying to kill you, because you shouldn't exist. Uyko has to deal with a split personality, or also called dissociative identity disorder that formed during his worl travelings. He was trying to find you all along, killing you with his own hands but also trying to save you and make you live. This time he wants to make up for it, and he does pretty well. Although he warns you and tells you that he is dangerous, you won't be able to let go of him. You will love him because you will realize how much you mean to him and if you're going the right path you will realize that it was him all along.

Personal opinionI am not a novel reader, and I bought Amnesiaâ„¢: Memories because I saw it on a sale. And after completing one walkthrough around the story with Shin, I just quit and didn't touch the novel for a couple of months. After all I realized how interesting it can get, and how many emotions the game calls up on you. I don't regret spending that much time in it, it was a pleasure getting all endings and completing the achievements. I totally fell in love with Toma because I am a little psycho myself, but honestly Ukyo is my favorite. Just the whole story about how he is only trying to find a world both you and him can live in is beautiful and has a huge meaning to me.
Overall there's nothing I'm disliking or missing for this visual novel. I mean it even got an anime and both are comparable with each other. It's awesome seeing and hearing heroine and the boys, so I highly recommend watching it after completing the game. Why after? Because you will just spoil yourself trying to get a good ending somehow with avoiding things you've seen in the anime. They are a little bit different. The story is the same but some things aren't mentioned in both the novel and anime, so you'll be better off doing work alone or walking through the novel with guides, which you should preferably do when having finished one ending in each route.
I'll give this game a 10/10, because this is the best thing I've ever read and I wouldn't mind spending the rest of money I haven't during the sale, because this is definitely worth buying for full price. As long as you're not some dude expecting nudity, because there won't be any.

reviewText:
Amnesiaâ„¢: Memories is a fantastic game. Truly an otome game after my own heart, portrayed in a way that's great for those who are not generally fans of the gaming genre or looking to play their first one. Possessing beautiful graphics, an A+ storyline, as well as characters each with their own distinct opinions, feelings and identities, this game was well-worth the time I put into it and hopefully the start of many more otome games to come (to Steam). I found this game to be unique in it's large cast of characters and the relationship dynamics between them, both romantic and platonic. As well as the heroine there are three other girls, Sawa, Mine, and Rika (plus Ikki's crazy fangirls), who each have unique relationships between eachother and the heroine, and of course Waka, the manager, the authority figure of the group who while his personality might change from world to world, his essence does not. The verisimilitude of this game brought about by these dynamics was truly a breath of fresh air. Of course, no game is perfect. There seem to be issues with recieving the Steam achievments for this game (hopefully that will be fixed, the game is still quite new), I found Ukyo's good end to be a little anti-climatic (I'd already seen the anime, so that probably had an impact), the backgrounds were somewhat underwhelming (pointed out to me while I was broadcasting this game to a friend, though I think it helps to not distract from the characters), Orion was used a little too much to portray the characters thoughts and feelings (of course, due to their bond he would know all about them), and I was a little concerned about how in Toma's good end after escaping the cage, kissing and making up with Toma, the topic of Toma's mental health and his extreme actions in locking the heroine in a cage for her protection were never properly adressed and discussed. This game does possess some subjects that while horror visual novel fans might love, some might find triggering. This isn't an innocent, cutesy otome game. While there's no sex, there are mentions of it in discussions, as well as gory off-screen deaths involving fire, knives, roofs, etc. Plus Toma's cage *shudders*.

So to sum it up;
great game,
well-developed characters,
unique storyline,
a perfect start for those looking to try their first otome game or who are not generally fans of the genre,
hopefully the start of many an otome game to come to Steam.
If this looks like a game you would enjoy and you have money to spare I reccomend you purchase the game, both for the game itself and to show Steam and game developers that otome games have a viable market here.

Editional comments: I broadcasted this game while playing to a few of my friends. One friend's favourite character was Shin, another's Toma, and mine Ukyo (his hair is ever so long and pretty, and he's a photographer).
P.s. All my Steam friends are male.
P.s.s. Need to make more female friends.

reviewText:
Overall I really enjoyed this game, but like a lot of otome games it has some problematic aspects along with the good ones.

First, the art is really beautiful even if the characters' outfits are completely, hilariously absurd. All of the sprites and CGs are really pretty, and the backgrounds are sort of a muted colors with white.

Unlike some otome games where you spend the first part of the game getting to know the characters and then figuring out which ones you want to romance, this game makes you choose immediately and then you are locked into that guy's route and can only succeed or fail (spectacularly) at it.

The good part about this is that the stories for each guy are very different, and as your character starts with amnesia (like the title) the mysterious and unknown parts of your life are different between routes. The relationships you have to the love interests and other characters change, which is really interesting and gives the game a lot of replayability since each route is basically its own thing.

The stories are all very engaging, but there are some definite yandere aspects to some of the relationships, so if that isn't your cup of tea you may want to look into which guys have that before playing so that you can avoid those routes. Or choose them, I guess, if you want to be locked in a cage by a possessive crazy person. :)

The bad ends definitely kill you, and since the MC has amnesia, she does tend to fall into the otome heroine trope of being fairly passive. There's a story reason for it, obviously, but if you're looking for a spunky MC with her own personality you won't find that here. MC has a few moments, but she's clearly intended to be pretty bland so that you can read whatever you want into her.

I recommend this game, it's a beautiful game with an engaging story, but it's definitely a Japanese otome game in a lot of ways which can be a good or  bad thing depending on how you look at it.

reviewText:
An official Otomate game on steam that should be played by every otome player. This isn't an indie title or an OELVN, this is one of the most popular otome titles in Japan by one of the largest otome game companies localized for PC. The game goes for $80+ or more in Japan, so $30 is more than worth the price of the game's content. It also gets a lot of discounted sales, so there is no reason to not buy this.

If you haven't watched the anime, I would suggest playing the game first. Also, consider using a random playing card generator to pick your route order, it was really fun for me lol. Playing in the order from top to bottom is best though.

+ Art is top notch quality and absolutely beautiful. Gorgeous colors, complex character designs, and a multitude of CGs. Although the backgrounds are a little weak, you don't spend too much time in one place.
+ Japanese voice acting is and always will be an A+ for any game. Personally, I put the text speed to 0, so the text could match up with the spoken dialogue length.
+ The routes are long. Multiple endings add a lot of replayability.
+ A great choice system that applies to you (the player) and the heroine's personality. The consequences do matter as you could put yourself into a bad ending. Getting the good endings without a guide was extremely satisfying for me. The effort to reach all the endings don't require walkthroughs (though tempting), it just requires a lot of patience (a quick save/load function would have been appreciated).
+ A strong mystery story and good use of the amnesia trope. The routes cover entirely different storylines with an overlapping mystery that is revealed through the final route. The story reaches a satisfying conclusion, although bittersweet, and should answer all questions.
+ Strong character personalities that go beyond otome stereotypes, I was thoroughly surprised that Ikki became my favorite guy when I had written him off as the player type.
+ A lot of extras such as short stories, minigames, and nice CG rewards for being a completionist
+ I prefer a balance between story and romantic scenes, which Amnesia does right. There are cute moments and sexual tension scenes. Ikki managed to make me blush after trying hard not to. I felt satisfied with each world's relationships *except Toma's
+/- The minigames in the menu aren't utilized in the main game at all, even though there are scenes where the minigames could have been used. For that reason, they felt more like an afterthought as an extra. Also, the air hockey minigame has unexplainable lag, which makes it frustrating to beat, but not impossible.
+/- Music is so-so. It sets the mystery (with a bit of horror) mood, but no tracks really stood out to me.

*A note for achievement advice: the gallery has a hidden minigame. The rose stickers on certain CGs have voice clips hidden in several spots of the photo (follow the controls). I can confirm that you must do this in ONE SITTING to unlock the achievement. Thoroughly click all over the pictures because there is about 6-7 dialogues each (don't forget the variations and zooming out).

Overall, Amnesia has become one of my favorite otome games and I really hope the other titles (Crowd, World, and Later) can be localized.

reviewText:
TL;DR: 4/5. One of the best otome game I've played so far. I highly recommend it!

---

Warning: This review may contain spoilers.

In Amnesia: Memories, you first open your eyes to a vast empty space which - you soon learn - is the gateway to many parallel realities. You then meet a spirit (Orion) who basically tells you that he's stuck inside your consciousness; his collision being the cause of your memory loss. The first major choice you make in the game is to pick which reality/world you came from: Heart, Spade, Clover or Diamond, i.e. according to the motifs associated with each of your love interests. There's also an unlockable world (Joker) you can only get after achieving good endings in the other realities.

Story: (5/5)
Unlike many other visual novels in which you gradually form a relationship with your chosen love interest, I find it refreshing that in Amnesia: Memories you're already in one at the very start. The five routes (worlds) have a similar theme of you having some sort of relationship issues (plus the memory loss), but the plot in each is very different - giving the game a high replay value. Some of the minor characters even have completely different personalities: most notably, Waka, the manager of cafÃ© you work at. Each route took me about 5-7 hours to complete and the game, around 30 hours.

While there are some internal monologues at the end of each route, you are entirely silent unless making a choice. Because of this, I feel that it is easy to get immersed in the story. It's like you're holding a conversation (although one-sided) with Orion throughout the game. Don't worry though, he knows when to make himself scarce during the more romantic scenes.

The story itself is lighthearted at the beginning, but around the halfway mark it becomes more suspenseful, tragic and even creepy in some storylines; Toma's (Diamond) route in particular (and Ikki's fangirls). The whole incident where he drugs you and put you in a cage made me very uncomfortable; and the fact that we're (as the main character) expected to just forgive him to get the good ending left me really baffled. Other than that, I truly enjoyed the other routes with Kent's (Clover) and Ukyo's (Joker) being the stand out. At least Kent's route provides some reprieve from the craziness of Ikki's fanclub. And Ukyo...I can probably write an essay on how I feel about his story but I'll just say it's worth experiencing for yourself.

There are also a few things I feel that aren't as clearly explained (e.g. the wishes, Lord Nhil and the world Orion came from) but overall it's very well-written with only a few, minor typos. I also want to mention the various instances where characters tease you with obscure(?) hints (spoilers really) of what can happen to you in the other routes. I find these very amusing especially if you only realize it after playing a few times.

Gameplay: (3/5)
The game plays like a basic VN with dialogue branches and unlockable CGs. There are unfortunately only 24 save slots in the game. I would've much preferred to keep all my saves instead of having to overwrite each time I start on a new route. If there is a way to watch the complete ending scenes again, I wouldn't mind as much. But since there's not, I think the game could do with unlimited save slots.

The game provides you with a 'Parameter' system (shown on the 3rd screenshot) to check the status of your relationship and maybe which ending you get in the end(?), but I think it is a bit unnecessary. The 'Suspicion' meter, in particular, maxes out at some point in the story no matter what you do anyway.

The 2 mini games available are simple, short and somewhat enjoyable. What I do appreciate about the Rock-Paper-Scissors mini game is the Hit 'N' Guard mechanic that ensures it relies less on luck and more on your reflexes. It does make the mini game way easier however.

There are also a few extra content unlocked after finishing the game including short stories told from the perspective of the love interests that I find interesting. I recommend reading at least Ukyo's.

Controls: (3/5)
I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the keyboard (and gamepad?) controls are re-bindable. Although I don't think I would ever need to re-bind anything for this particular game, I do appreciate the devs putting that feature in regardless. I do wish there was an option to skip the story after picking a choice, but other than that, I have nothing bad to say about the options menu.

Graphics: (5/5)
Practically every character in the game is gorgeously designed, and every voiced dialogue is accompanied by effective use of expressions and eye blinking. The stylized backdrops with little tints of color suit the game in my opinion and makes it look very surreal/dream-like in its simplicity. A close-up of the curtains at the Shinano mountain lodge in a few conversations, however, looked very messy and amateurish but that's just me nitpicking.

Sound: (4/5)
The voice acting for all the characters are done very professionally by accomplished voice actors. There are no English voices but the high quality of the Japanese voices more than makes up for it. The lip syncing is just okay; it's a bit distracting when their mouths move even when they're not actually saying anything. Tracks used for the background music are generally soft and tranquil but slightly repetitive. I can listen to the opening song all day though and to a lesser extent, the ending song as well.

Conclusion:
A must try for fans of the genre. I can't say if it's worth it for $30 since I bought it on sale. But for $3, I would definitely recommend buying it.

reviewText:
I had the privilege of beta testing this game and I must say it is very much worth the money!

Any otome fan or visual novel fan is sure to like this one, it is probably the best otome game I've played, and the localization team did excellent work.

The premise of the story is that you play as a nameable heroine who has had an encounter with an otherworldly being and as a result of that, she loses all her memories. The story is told in a very interesting way compared to most visual novels as you choose the character route at the beginning of the game, and the goal of the game being to get that character's best possible ending. (All characters have bad endings, normal endings, and good endings.)

One of my favourite things about Amnesia: Memories was that it really builds on the characters as you play, and you sympathize with the heroine as just like her you know nothing about the bachelors and have to learn about them. There was a particular bachelor that I started out hating, and the heroine didn't care much for either - but as you gain her memories back you start to gain insight into these characters and begin to care for them - with this, the game does a great job of putting you in her shoes.

In short, I honestly recommend this game if you're looking for a great otome game with cute anime boys, pretty visuals, and great music. I hope we get to see more otome games in the future! Thank you Idea Factory International!

reviewText:
This is the first dating sim and the first visual novel I've ever played.  I bought it entirely on a whim, mostly because it was on sale.
And I LOVED IT.

Pros:

-Compelling storyline with multiple endings

-Parameter system is quite helpful to find out how you are doing

Cons:
-There is the need to save spam in some instances, or you might die unexpectedly and lose a lot of progress
-Your helper spirit, Orion can be pretty annoying at some parts and is a master of stating the obvious
-Parameter system, while helpful, can't tell you what the boys actually want, leading to some frustration.
(For example, in one route I got a bad ending due to having too much suspicion. After restarting saves, micromanging descisions, and starting the route over again, I had to look up a walkthrough to find out that you have to be super lovey-dovey. but those descisions made him super suspicous so I always rejected those choices, leading to a getting an ending where he was too suspicious of me even though my suspision was as low as possible. Wow that was a long tangent/rant. Anyway.)
-One storyline is a bit fetish specific and may to off putting to everyone else
-The achievments are bit broken, for me at least. Totally did what the achievement told me to, but Steam won't give me it

Conclusion:
The pros massiy outway the cons. I really really enjoyed 4 out of 5 routes (sorry, just not into yanderes). This game is good for hardcore dating sim fans and people with just a passing interest, like me.

reviewText:
I don't normally write reviews, but this visual novel has left an exceptional impression on me. Since this game is nothing but story, I'll try to keep it spoiler-free.

(Side-note: This visual novel has an anime! It's crap compared to the game though, so I don't recommend that)

Overall Positive Features:

Story - This is the most important part of the game, so respectfully it's the best part. There are five arcs to this game, each pertaining to one of the five main male characters. Even if you aren't the biggest fan of the main male character to the arc, the heroine's relationship to him is generally not the only focus of the story, so it's still enjoyable.

Japanese Voice-acting - the voice acting work of this game is well-done; character voices fit the personalities appropriately, and nobody sounds like an emotionless brick unless they're supposed to.

Character art and CGs - The design of the characters and the CGs are really nice in my opinion- even if you're really stingy about art, the designs are at the very least tolerable.

Music - The soundtrack of this game is fantastic and fits the mood extremely well. The song for the opening movie also has a lot of hype, I love it.

Things You May Find Iffy:

Orion - Orion is a character that is with you throughout the entire game and provides commentary on what's happening around you for the majority of the game. He's also extremely important to the plot, so even if you don't like him, you're stuck with him. Personally I like Orion, but his constant presence can be annoying to players. Since you can't 'disable' him, it can ruin the game for you if you don't like him.

Background Art - I'll level with you. There's only like three or four colors along with some gradient in them most of the time, excluding white. I personally don't mind this since it allows me to focus on the characters in front of me rather than being distracted by a super-detailed background, but you may find it a bit too washed-out for your taste (check the screenshots on the store page to see if you like it or not).

Bonus:

Endings - This game has A LOT of endings. Every arc has at least four endings: The good ending, the normal ending, and at least two bad endings, with a total of 26 endings.

Memories & Extras - Okay, so at some point, you will unlock the item Memories" for the main menu. The Memories are little bonus scenes where the heroine spends time with that character at some point during the story. Next
date: there's the item "Extras" which you also unlock at some point for the main menu. These are basically silent thoughts from the main male of a particular arc. And by silent

If you want a taste (or some preview) of the game, may contain some spoilers though, watch the anime. If you just want to take a look what the story is about, watch episode 1. The heroine in the anime is kind of annoying though, looks like she isn't capable of doing anything, in the game she (you) is much more fun :)

reviewText:
Different worlds, different relationships, different levels of creep.
That'd have to be the easiest way I could define this.
And this isn't even a horror game.

Having played all three of the games, I was really glad to see this make it to Steam. This is one of the better Otome games out there, having various elements that actually make the gameplay interesting and not only sticking to lovey-dovey stuff (but worry not, there's plenty of that~).

Each of the four (cough, five) men that you get to pick have their own stories, their own hardships, their own strong personalities. I must remind you of what I said earlier though, every single one of them is a creep in their own way -cough- cage, murder, math (because seriously, why math...), over-the-top playboy or more lies than I'd probably ever told.

And yet you still choose to love and date those creeps because you're no better than them, with your adorable little spirit that's teaching you how to deceive others to hide your amnesia.

This is life at its finest, ladies. Possibly gents aswell. I hope you all enjoy the ride as much as I did.

reviewText:
It's not often that you'll hear me, of all people, make a statement like this, but I genuinely feel bad that I got this game at such a high discount. I bought Amnesia when it was 90% off for the winter sale, and it's certainly one of the best visual novels I've ever played.

For one thing, this game is just incredibly well-made. Now, a good 90% of the visual novels I've played have been freeware ones I've found online across various forums. None of them have had particularly high production values or anything like that; at most they've feature a couple of CGs and a bonus scene or some questions answered by the creator about their game, but besides that they're pretty basic. To get a game with so many CGs, which are remarkably well-drawn and colored; voice acting; an awesome soundtrack (I may or may not have gotten about 60-65% of my playing hours for this game by just leaving it open while I did other stuff on my computer in different windows, just because I really liked the music); mini-games (albeit ones with rather poor controls in several cases, though that may be due to my mouse being particularly terrible);  and over 20 different endings is a completely new experience for me. It's been somewhat hard for me to go back to playing games without most of these nice features, or at least where these features aren't as well done as they are in Amnesia. I feel like I stole something by getting a game this nice for only three dollars.

But speaking of all of those endings I mentioned, let me discuss the actual routes and characters, since they make up a bulk of the game's experience. The routes are set in different alternate 'worlds', each of which is named after suits on playing cards. Please note that you should probably play the routes in the order they're listed as choices; I made the mistake of playing Toma's route first, since he was the only character I was curious about going in, and I can't help but feel like I would've enjoyed the game that much more if I had just chosen his route last. (In Shin's route, at least, things become a *lot* more predictable once you know the sort of stunts Toma's capable of pulling.) Each route has a good end, a normal end, and several bad ends. Note: there's 5 routes to play, not 4, but the fifth is only unlockable after you've done the others.

Now onto the characters themselves. For the most part, I thought all the romanceable guys were pretty likeable and well-portrayed. Not all of them strike me as 'boyfriend' material, but nonetheless, every one of them was quite interesting in his own right. While the guys are essentially stock otome love interests- we have a blunt tsundere with a heart of gold, a chivalrous playboy whose only *sincere* romantic interest is in you (the heroine), a logical and seemingly cold (but entirely adorkable) nerd, and a yandere willing to do anything to protect you- they're all either played to perfection or with an interesting twist on the usual 'type'.

My personal favorite character is Ikki, which says a lot, since I typically dislike the 'playboy' type (if I don't ignore them as an option altogether). But Ikki was sweet and had quite a bit more depth to his character than I was expecting, and several times I really wanted to hug him because I felt so badly for him. That said, I don't think I actually disliked any of the love interests, at least not in retrospect. Some of them made me very frustrated, and some of the routes were outright morally compromising (I'm looking at you, Toma), but they were really enjoyable overall. Hell, Toma's route was the first one I wanted to replay- I don't like him as a love interest, particularly, but he was damn entertaining.

And while I haven't said anything about Ukyo, he was a different sort of character than I've dealt with in any otome game before. I'm still not quite sure what to make of his route. I will once again offer a bit of advice and say this: DO NOT LOOK UP ANYTHING RELATED TO UKYO UNTIL YOU'VE PLAYED THROUGH HIS ROUTE AT LEAST ONCE. Once again, I made the mistake of spoiling the twist with him before I even unlocked his route, which took away a lot of his charm for me. Instead, playing through his route was something of a drag because I didn't have to piece together any of his cryptic statements or anything.

This whole review has turned into one long TL;DR, so I'll say this in conclusion: Amnesia was a thoroughly enjoyable game. Even the characters who I didn't particularly like as love interests were quite entertaining regardless, and this is certainly the most professional, well-presented otome game- or visual novel in general- that I've ever played. I probably would've liked it even more had I not spoiled some major aspects of the story for myself, but even given that, Amnesia totally won me over. I'd love to see more on Steam from Idea Factory in the future.

reviewText:
Amnesia is seriously a really god game! Sure, it's not quite worth $30 (I waited for the Christmas sale and hooked a great deal!) but if you're really into replaying games over and over again to try new and different things, this is certainly the game for you. The characters (as well as their designs) really stick out, and everyone each has their own set personalities that really make playing the game over and over again enjoyable.


There are a bunch of pros (the characters, the different endings for each set storyline) and cons (solving actual math problems to get a good relationship up) but all in all I really do suggest getting this game  when there's a sale tbh  but if playing otome games is your thing, I really do suggest buying this game. If you're not into semi-long paths for various characters (as well as solving math problems in one of those paths) as well as playing a general otome game, this game isn't for you.

9/10!  Still not over having to do math

Pros:

-Original japanese voiceovers

-The game doesn't seem translated at all until the game setting (Tokyo) reminds you of it, the translated lines feel very natural

Cons:

-Somewhat boring background music
-Orion talks too much and is a little too excitable at times and some of his suggestion don't make sense
-The spade route felt a little over the top, the supernatural charm and fan club were too much compared to some of the other routes.

All in all the game was very enjoyable and I even pulled an all nighter to see what happened next. I can't recommend this game enough to people who like otome games.

-The stories were very enjoyable even though they did feel a little predictable at times
-The game doesn't seem translated at all until the game setting (Tokyo) reminds you of it, the translated lines feel very natural

Cons:
-Somewhat boring background art
-Somewhat boring background music
-Orion talks too much and is a little too excitable at times and some of his suggestion don't make sense
-The spade route felt a little over the top, the supernatural charm and fan club were too much compared to some of the other routes.

All in all the game was very enjoyable and I even pulled an all nighter to see what happened next. I can't recommend this game enough to people who like otome games.

Steam sorely needed another otome game made by a studio that's been in this business for years.  Since Steam's change in discount policy, Amnesia has been on sale for $3 after 90% discount.  That alone should be enough to invest at least 3 hours of your time in a guy you're interested in.  Side note, you can't just call off the relationship with a guy in the world you pick, because this type of game is built with the assumption that you intend to pursue these guys.  It's $3 worth of silly writing, romance, and good-looking guys.  Now... Reasons why $3 is worth your time...

Likes
1.  Character and CG art are done well.  The artist does a good enough job with mixing up different viewing angles of the scene, but the placement of hair or other parts of the characters makes the viewing angles of their faces look weird (i.e. their noses seem to disappear).  Similarly to CG viewing angles, it was a nice touch to have character sprites facing the player in order to convey a sense of direction.  Likewise, these additions add to some imagination that two characters are directly looking at each other.  There's also lip movement when characters talk so the player isn't staring at stiff mouths all the time.

2.  Plots for 4/5 guys are done well in the sense that it's not romance-focused, but more mystery-focused as the player pieces together what happened before the heroine lost her memories.  At the same time, the player has to take care to not max out the suspicion parameter lest that triggers bad endings or characters may take advantage of that.

3.  Each guy has a distinct archetype so the player can freely pick any to start.  Overall, Shin and Toma are the childhood friends (i.e. romantically aggressive and romantically a doormat, in that order); Ikki, Kent, and Ukyo (<- unlocked after playing the other 4) are the older guys roughly ages 21-26 (i.e. not-typical-playboy; stoic, logical guy; and aloof romanticist).  Word of advice: Don't pick Toma's route (Diamond world) if you're not familiar with an archetype made popular with Mirai Nikki.

Dislikes
1.  Whoever wrote Orion's lines needs to be suspended for a while.  A lot of people hate hearing Orion, and I agree in that Orion was the weakest link.  Although I appreciated Orion's hinting of how to respond to specific situations, his role as the heroine's voice and partner-in-crime was horrible.  The game's rated T for Teens, but Orion's regurgitation of really obvious information and constant attempts to get you to doubt everything were patronizing at best, and very insulting at worst to the average 13-19 yr old's reading and problem-solving skills (or am I giving teens too much credit?).  Furthermore, taking his advice seriously in Ikki's route(Spade) can get you the bad ending quickly.  Likewise, Orion forgot to remind the heroine to read her diary in Toma's route (Diamond) which would've saved a lot of headache.

2.  Beyond Orion, writing is very spotty in Toma's route and a bit in Ikki's route.  Logic was missing and anyone who understood dramatic irony can piece together the mysteries quickly, which makes Orion's remarks even more irritating.  Overall, the heroine is written so then she only has more lines after she regains her memories.  Before she gets all of her memories back, she is practically silent except when picking dialogue choices.  I'm sure people don't stay silent all the time just because some memories are missing, especially if it's a survival issue of not letting others know they have amnesia.  Something to keep in mind is that the almost-silent heroine exists because it's a common storytelling device to allow the players to project themselves onto her (e.g. Persona 3 and 4's silent protagonists... except they had personalities too...).  While I wouldn't mind it in an otome game, this storytelling device was done poorly and if you want a voiced otome heroine, look to Hakuoki: Demon of the Fleeting Blossom, Code: Realize, or Norn9: Var Commons.  The wording of the dialogue choices can be frustrating sometimes, because there are the obvious ones and the less obvious ones that boost the trust and affection parameters.

3.  A minor dislike in the backgrounds.  Although stylistic and doesn't clash with character art, the resolution was noticeably awful when zoomed in for the purpose of perspective.  Not only was the resolution bad, but the backgrounds don't look like they were manually drawn and look like filtered photos.

4.  Getting the air hockey achievement wouldn't be so bad if the devs just optimized the friggin' game.  The lag is intense and there has already been a major thread providing self-taught solutions to minimizing the lag so the mini-game can be tolerable.

Final Say
For $3, you can't go wrong with purchasing this game if you're into the otome visual novel genre.  Just think of it as a discounted game that can provide you with a light story and some laughs along the way.  Be aware that this game was released a couple of years ago by the Japanese company, Otomate.  Why emphasize the Japanese" part?  Because there are plenty of non-Japanese gamers who were instantly turned off by a silent heroine and some of the things the guys say (e.g. "Watch your surroundings full of guys oogling your bikini"
date: "Don't you know it's dangerous to invite a guy to your room when living alone?"
recommended: "I don't know if I can control my urges" etc) because part of the writing is influenced by Japanese storytelling targeted at Japanese women."

When it comes to otome games I find it quite hard to find good ones, and I was still quite sceptical when I started playing Amnesia. But it didn't disappoint me at all.\nWould recommend it if you like beautiful art combined with a plot with a twist.

As like many Otome games, there is obviously a lack of realism. However, trudging through some of the weird premise that all the boys love you without any memories, you'll find a pretty intricate foundation for the world of Amnesia. I found it pretty fascinating in the aspect for world building. I've always been interested in a visual novel that basically goes backwards (due to amnesia).  Story-wise, it's a lot deeper than it appears. It may seem shallow at first, but once added together it has some depth and darkness. It's eerily dark and convoluted for an otome, actually.

A note: Unfortunately, I wouldn't recommend it to a male audience. I imagine it would be well welcomed by girls (because it's made for girls). The game is also based on Japanese culture, so some parts may not relatable to a Western audience(?).

Game-wise, while I enjoyed the routes to some degree, half of the characters lacked the development they needed/deserved in their respective routes. A lot of issues especially with Toma and Ukyo are shoved under the rug rather than resolved in a constructive and healthy way. I'm assuming that this may be addressed in the sequel games (Amnesia Later).

I really like the characters themselves! Possibly the only reason I continued to read. Their relationship web, aside from the MC, made them a lot more likable. I'm also a sucker for reminiscing in any medium.

reviewText:
As I've played the game in its original language, I can say that this english version has lost much of its unique puzzle portion in translation. Politeness levels in speech are found in Japanese and not English, so, half of the satisfaction in reading and decoding the social atmosphere and returning the correct polite/casual answers without raising suspicion is gone.

Despite its shortcomings, uncovering of the individual stories and the overarching plot is still very much enjoyable, and this game's format has taken great pains to preserve the feeling of natural conversation as one of its unique points, from the way the dialogue is written to the way the speech is presented in game as speech bubbles and not text boxes.

The HD graphics upgrade compared to the tiny resolution of the PSP is a big plus as well.
Although there is some minor quality fluctuations (the blue swirly background at the beginning has artifacts leftover from upscaling for example) in this HD localised port, it's of little importance compared to the gloriousness of HD beautiful boys and sexy Japanese voice acting that they kept.

Drool away, ladies, and don't forget to find the numerous drama CDs and character songs if you can understand Japanese (and also the three to four spinoffs in this series that they haven't translated).

The game's rated T for Teens, but Orion's regurgitation of really obvious information and constant attempts to get you to doubt everything were patronizing at best, and very insulting at worst to the average 13-19 yr old's reading and problem-solving skills (or am I giving teens too much credit?).  Furthermore, taking his advice seriously in Ikki's route(Spade) can get you the bad ending quickly.  Likewise, Orion forgot to remind the heroine to read her diary in Toma's route (Diamond) which would've saved a lot of headache.

2.  Beyond Orion, writing is very spotty in Toma's route and a bit in Ikki's route.  Logic was missing and anyone who understood dramatic irony can piece together the mysteries quickly, which makes Orion's remarks even more irritating.  Overall, the heroine is written so then she only has more lines after she regains her memories.  Before she gets all of her memories back, she is practically silent except when picking dialogue choices.  I'm sure people don't stay silent all the time just because some memories are missing, especially if it's a survival issue of not letting others know they have amnesia.  Something to keep in mind is that the almost-silent heroine exists because it's a common storytelling device to allow the players to project themselves onto her (e.g. Persona 3 and 4's silent protagonists... except they had personalities too...).  While I wouldn't mind it in an otome game, this storytelling device was done poorly and if you want a voiced otome heroine, look to Hakuoki: Demon of the Fleeting Blossom, Code: Realize, or Norn9: Var Commons.  The wording of the dialogue choices can be frustrating sometimes, because there are the obvious ones and the less obvious ones that boost the trust and affection parameters.

3.  A minor dislike in the backgrounds.  Although stylistic and doesn't clash with character art, the resolution was noticeably awful when zoomed in for the purpose of perspective.  Not only was the resolution bad, but the backgrounds don't look like they were manually drawn and look like filtered photos.

4.  Getting the air hockey achievement wouldn't be so bad if the devs just optimized the friggin' game.  The lag is intense and there has already been a major thread providing self-taught solutions to minimizing the lag so the mini-game can be tolerable.

Final Say
For $3, you can't go wrong with purchasing this game if you're into the otome visual novel genre.  Just think of it as a discounted game that can provide you with a light story and some laughs along the way.  Be aware that this game was released a couple of years ago by the Japanese company, Otomate.  Why emphasize the Japanese" part?  Because there are plenty of non-Japanese gamers who were instantly turned off by a silent heroine and some of the things the guys say (e.g. "Watch your surroundings full of guys oogling your bikini"
date: "Don't you know it's dangerous to invite a guy to your room when living alone?"
recommended: "I don't know if I can control my urges" etc) because part of the writing is influenced by Japanese storytelling targeted at Japanese women."

reviewText:
Amnesia memories is, in my opinion, one of the top (officially) released games available to the pc otome english market.
The characters do not fall under monotonous personalities of slightly changed versions of one another, nor does the story. While every character is integrated in each others stories one way or the other, they tend to be quite different in every one of them, showing that they have a (non stale bread) personality even if they aren't part of the heroine's main story, and that their personality does not revolve around her existing. The heroine barely talks in most routes, since Orion does most of the talking, so, if you come from the anime and hated her in that, this might be a plus for you.
I have not finished yet all the routes, but from how far i have gotten i have to say i have not gotten dissapointed in the writing (aside from some plot holes).  Love how this allows you to die, as well as for your boyfriends not being perfect ~~uguu angels~~ all the time even in good routes, i'm glad that the creators of this game don't mind stepping on certain toes and decided to keep it true to the original japanese release (as far as i'm concerned).
Characters are beautifully designed, amzing color palettes, not too weird anatomy or clothes and the most important thing beautiful beautiful 2D men on my screen.
Each story is impressively well thought out and can fit in quite a bit of personality preferences you might have without screwing you over in story, so just because you might like a possesive guy his story isn't gonna be less good than the charming suave one, each story seems equally thought out and developed.
Backgrounds are beautiful albeit a bit repetitive, though they are muted out and not too in your face, so it doesn't really matter.
As for the techical side, it runs smoothly, a lot of customization in settings, controller support, clean interface, sikp only read text option, key mapping, non annoying stat bars, amazing voice actors, responsive and smooth transitions, very good translation, a lot of endings, quite a bit of mini games (if you count unlockable ones), incredibly good soundtrack, and lovely LOVELY CG.
If you are interested in otome games, or dating sims in general, i seriously cannot recommend this game enough.

I personally love this game! The voice acting is great and it has great music. Also, the artwork is amazing and so pretty. This game is very well made. There is not much else to say or then that this is a very good otome game.\nSo, if you like anime or manga (or both), then you will enjoy playing this game.\n

reviewText:
A fantastic Otome and one of the best I've ever played.

The mystery and drama surrounding all of the characters is enough to draw in even those who are not into the romantic aspect of it, but do be warned it is in fact heavily based in romance.

It is a fairly linear game, but it makes up for it by having three ends (good, neutral, bad) for every guy and a lot of unlockables.

The character art is fairly good but the rest of the art is pretty lacking. You'll be seeing a lot of the same blurry backdrops over and over, but the engaging story more than makes up for it.

Unravel the mystery of who you are and fall in love over and over again.

I strongly recommend this game to anyone and everyone as long as you're able to get it at a reasonable price. I can fully understand why $30 for an Otome may seem like a lot to people not familiar with the genre.

reviewText:
[Disclaimer: In no way, shape, or form was I compensated for the composition or publication of this review. This by my own volition. A review copy of the game was kindly provided by Ideal Factory International.]

Developed by Idea Factory under its Otome game brand Otomate, Amnesia: Memories is among one of the companies pioneering titles that finally gets a western release. And while Otoge or Otome games are meant to cater specifically toward a female audience, a male audience can also partake of them. The story puts players into the shoes of an unnamed female protagonist that has lost her memories after a strange incident. With help of mysterious young boy named Orion, the two work together to help make sense of the heroineâ€™s past life, while trying not raise suspicion from friends and a boyfriend she never knew existed.

With Amnesia: Memories actually being my first Otome game and looking that is from the perspective of a newcomer, I do think that first timers like myself or those completely new to visual novels in general will be able to navigate it easily. For one, before you even start to meet the eligible bachelors, you will be able to choose who you want to interact with from the start by choosing a world â€“ each holding a symbolic card corresponding to that person. You have the aloof Shin of the â€œHeartâ€ world, playboy Ikki of the â€œSpadeâ€ world, his logical best friend Kent of â€œClubâ€ world, and the big brother figure Toma of â€œDiamnondâ€ world. There is a fifth guy and the route that puts all this into perspective, but needs to be unlocked by completing the others. Not only do each the routes play out differently depending on the world, but also changes how certain people will treat you. For instance, Waka, the manager at the place the herione works at is very nice in the â€œHeartâ€ route, but his personality does shift greatly in others â€“ going from docile to abrasive. This does apply to the other characters you meet as well to varying degrees, and serves as a nice change of pace to see how each route differs despite the feature being nothing new to visual novels.

Even though the main love interest and their personalities play into the typical paradigm most shoujo anime seems to reach for, I did honestly enjoy exploring the backstories of the guys I did go after. My favorite character would have to be the titular Shin, learning the reason behind his distant attitude that stems from a past event with his father. The writing is very simple in many ways and not that great when it comes to giving the story some interesting twist and turns, but still okay in its own right. The individual routes are fine on their own, but overall does fall short of being particularly great. Thatâ€™s all I can offer on the subject without spoiling it. By the same admission, the characters themselves also arenâ€™t as detailed as they could be, but still found them interesting. Especially in the case of Toma. Yup, veryâ€¦ fascinating personality shift for that guy.

Getting back to gameplay, the same orthodox process of reading text and making decisions at certain points become the norm like most visual novels, with one exception. Keeping with the theme of trying to piece together your life without letting your boyfriend be any wiser, the choices you make do have implications on 3 values: â€œAffectionâ€, â€œTrustâ€, and â€œSuspicionâ€. The goal of is to ideally get a â€œGoodâ€ or â€œNormalâ€ ending by keeping your Affection and Trust values high and Suspicion low. Again, depending on the choices, these values will fluctuate, so it is important to be mindful of what choices you make and keep tabs on your parameter menu frequently. Often or not, it is pretty easy to know how to response, yet can abuse the system by saving your game and seeing how a certain choice goes. In the event that you do have your Suspicion high, the game will continue, but will be able to get a bad ending more easily from making a wrong choice or simply getting the normal ending for that route if you happen to make it through successfully. Since replay value is a big part of games of this nature, it doesnâ€™t hurt and obvious that making multiple saves will offer some assistance.

When you tire of trying to get through the story or even completed the game, besides viewing the CG library for illustrations, listening to tracks, or keeping track of the endings you received, the game does have two mini-games you can play at anytime: Rock-paper-scissors and Air hockey. There not the most interesting thing in the world, but itâ€™s there if you need it as a brief diversion. I would like to detail this section, but since I never actually won a game, I will leave the outcome of what happens (if anything) to be a surprise.

On the aesthetic side of things, the artwork and animation for the game is very impressive. In a lot ways, the color scheme and style used kind of reminds me of that found in Steins;Gate, despite not having the same exact appearance or as drab. Animations are crisp and lively, and actually show off a lot of technical muscle such as changing the characters sprite angles (seeing them from the side or back) that really makes them come alive without having to go toward excess. My favorite animation would have to be of Ikki holding his signature sunglasses and smoothly slipping them on in the same scene almost like it was in one movement. The musical score is very genteel and well-done, piano pieces being the most prominent holding up the sentimental mood â€“ that admittedly, tends get lost at various times. By the time you get through half of the routes it will become droning, yet mildly tolerable.

With visual novels gaining more acceptance and familiarity in the West, I do believe titles like Amnesia: Memories will be great boon for its biggest supporters. It definitely isnâ€™t the cream of crop, especially when it comes to the overall writing, but still fairly remarkable in other areas like presentation and making that presentation work for it during the course of the game. While it wonâ€™t be for a couple of months until see Idea Factoryâ€™s other Otome offerings, Amnesia is a pretty pleasant harbinger of what to expect and do think this one will keep most fans satisfied for the time being.

reviewText:
The graphics are pretty. The guys are relatively attractive. Most of the stories are detailed and interesting. However, I ended up not recommending the game due to Toma's story.

Toma's story is extremely awful. It involves abuse, Stockholm Syndrome, and r/a/p/e threats. No kidding. I honestly am not sure who in their right minds would think that this would be a good romantic story. It's a romance story turned into horror. All of the guys do problematic things at one point or another, but they're usually small things that can be overlooked and one can still enjoy the story. Toma's story is just wrong in so many ways that it's sickening that it was even in the game. Honestly, the best part about Toma's story was the normal ending, because the main character gets to escape him.

In one of the bad endings, Toma has the main character in chains, literally just a bunch of chains. Her memory is completely gone and she's dressed in a maid outfit. There's also the insinuation that he does whatever he wants with her, probably including r/a/p/e. Just to give you an idea of how horrifying this whole thing is.

If you get the game, please get it on sale and if you have experience with abusive relationships, I truly don't recommend going through Toma's story.

Otherwise, the game was interesting and fun to go through. It's such a shame that such a good game has been tarnished by one story in it.

reviewText:
Have you ever watched a Let's Play of a game? Have you ever watched one with an incredibly annoying narrator who talks about 10x more than the entire narration of the game and his attempts at being fun are just incredibly irritating?

Amnesia is an otome game about a girl who has lost her memories and must discover the truth behind who she is and her situation without arousing suspicion. You can choose from 4 different scenarios in which her life is different from each other. However, no matter which reality you pick, her life is pretty complicated, and you will need to get your bearings fast if you are to make the right choices. To make matters worse, in each world you are pursued by a green haired maniac hell bent on murdering you although the reasons aren't immediately apparent

Fortunately you have 4 hunks to help you out, though you can only pursue a relationship with one in each world. They each differ in personality and while they do have the typical Otome game borderline obsession with the comparatively bland protagonist it's very toned back in this game compared to your usual Otome game and they actually have conversations with you and other characters in which the subject of the conversation ISN'T you! For me this was a breath of fresh air since I was sick to death of the Twilight creepy obsession

I recommend this game, but only barely. And the reason for that is the opening paragraph of this review. For those of you who have played Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, you will probably understand what I mean right away. Remember that fairy Navi? This game makes me wish I could have her as my companion again

You will be followed throughout the game by a shota boy with a chipmunk voice who learned to speak from watching the entire 7 seasons of Buffy the Vampire Slayer. He gets 75% of the dialogue in the game, no more than 2 sentences can be spoken before he gives his long winded, annoying and completely unfunny commentary, and there's no way you can get this little pest to shut up! The only positive thing I have to say about him is that at least he isn't PewDiePie

I recommend this game, and I recommend that every time you see an Orion dialogue bubble you immediately click past it. Annoying shota chipmunk schyzophrenic delusions aside this is the pinnacle of Otome games, so I recommend it!

reviewText:
I've been dying for this game to come out ever since I saw the anime. So far it's really great. I really enjoy the style with the playing card motif as well as how the backgrounds look against the amazing artwork of the characters. The story is great and even better than the anime so far, so I'm pretty pleased.

The only downsides are more having to do with the actual port of the game to PC and it's translation, rather than the game itself. There's missing translations for the mini games which is disappointing, but it's still understandable enough to play them. I just cannot see why they didn't feel the need to translate their comments. It would've been great if they got the English voice actors from the anime as well but that isn't a must. The port to the PC is kinda strange with the full screen mode being very awkward when you have to tab+enter and click the x to exit out of the game. I also had some random fps issues but it seemed to clear up so not sure if that was on my end. It's better than not having a port to PC at all, but I do wish they'd do a better job next time.

Overall I'm glad to finally be able to play this game and hope we get more otome games localized in the future. I recommend it to anyone who likes romance, mystery or any kind of visual novel. The characters are all really interesting and it leaves you wanting to play it over and over to unlock all the endings and routes. Right now it's on sale and it'd be stupid not to grab it now, especially when it's worth it at the full price.
