reviewText:
Amnesia is one of those games that I heard about years ago and became desperate to play because of the art quality. It was a very highly received title in Japan as well.

Based on other otome I've played, I think this is... sort of junk food. Lots of people like it, but that doesn't make it good. Even from a graphic novel standpoint, it's not especially well put together. That said, if you like the premise and you like the fetishes the routes offer, of course you'll overlook these flaws. I'm the same way with other games.

My first issue was that you have to choose a route at the start of the game. There's no 'let's get to know the characters' thing before you choose a route, which is why I preferred when this sort of mechanic was used in Nameless.

As others said, you have a passive heroine. Normally, this would be ok, since most otome heroines are self-insert anyway, but she is notable among the genre for her debilitating lack of agency. Based on dialogue which hints at your pre-amnesiac self, it seems that you were a bit of a selfish, needy and demanding person before. The guys generally express a sort of relief with this new, placid 'you'. So, basically, the guys like you because you're pretty, regardless of how you act. There's not even the pretense of personality here and for me, that their standards are so shallow makes me like the bachelors way less. I can't even say it's misogynistic either, since your heroine also doesn't have much reason to like these characters besides their looks.

You get a good ending if you're agreeable, a bad ending if you're not. You start the routes essentially already in a relationship, so for me, that already negates one of the most engaging aspects of these sorts of games.

Both the characters and the storyline are borderline satire. The smart guy's shtick is that he's like a computer; the 'big bro' shtick is that he's crazy obsessed with you, but seems normal; the crazy guy is laughing maniacally one second and remorseful and moe the next; the story keeps making excuses as to why you can't just do the reasonable thing for the sake of pursuing romantic interests. One step more and this game would have gone into Hatoful Boyfriend territory with the ludicrous nature of it all.

In total, the game caters to the fetish of 'helplessness', which has seen growing popularity in both Japan and North America. Basically, you have determined love interests (no need to search), in pre-selected routes (no risk of not getting guy), where you have no memory (not accountable for past errors or responsibilities) which is caused by a supernatural force (no concerns over actual medical problems), who takes responsibility over not just your memory, but your relationship status (no need for hard decisions) and your boyfriend(s) routinely put in you in a position where 'they will take care of everything' and restrict your agency. There's segments in all the routes which basically have your heroine wait in her room for days at a time, with occasional visits from one of the bachelors.

For me, there are other English otome that did most of the elements presented in Amnesia much better. It's a shallow game that caters to the right niches. I don't condemn it for that - I just wish it had catered to mine!

My oh my, I have played/read a fair amount of VNs, but the writing of this one is on a whole new abysmal level...

Here's the short version: Bad pacing, too much convenience and a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ deus ex machina accompaning you sure ruin a story.

And now a bit of elaboration: This opinion is based on sitting through parts of the heart and spades route and mainly focus on the quality of the writing and to a degree the character design

First of all, in regards to the desgin, if the object (and let's face it it's little more than that) of interest of the spades route has a spade tatooed on his face, and yet somehow argues that sunglasses make the difference when it comes to recognition you know what to expect...

I already mentioned you being accompanied by an incarnated deus ex machina, otherwise know as Orion and I want him to die. In a fire for example, though I am not too picky, anything should do the job.

As the games premise is you, the protagonist, losing all of her memories, it'd reasonable to expect that you would mainly portray apathy towards all of the people you used to know as they're nothing but strangers to you now. Effectively whatever Orion says is what you say, even though he is supposed to be nonexistent fo ranyone but you, also he gets into it way too much...

TL;DR: Interesting stories with a lot of endings but clichÃ© characters.

I like it; the various worlds have very varied stories and it's fun to explore all the different endings.
Getting the good ending is not a constant guessing game, like in many VNs out there, as you can see what effect your answers have on the romance and trust bars.
The bachelors are very different but unfortunately they tend to lean on clichÃ© stereotypes (the intelligent, unemotional guy with glasses, anyone? Come on! That one could have been avoided, easily!)
The concept of various worlds and the whole creepy death vibe, while not entirely original, has an interesting twist to it. I warmly recommend it to VN-otome lovers.
This visual novel has made me experience slowly falling in love with characters I legit disliked in the beginning, something that no other visual novel has accomplished so far.

The artwork is the best I've seen, but that can only go so far; thankfully, there is really good writing incorporated into the game.  There isn't anything hentai-like, so you don't have to feel embarrassed if someone walks into your gaming sessions.  I've logged 60 hours on this game.   I wanted to complete everything and see every reaction because I got into it that much.  There was a lot resting on this game since it was the FIRST dating-sim  visual novel I ever played, it gave me a truly pleasant experience & left me with a such a positive impression of the genra that I'm hungry for more titles (that I hope can live up to this one). This game has romance and dating" but there ends up being such a clever story and enough mystery during the playthrough that it keeps things interesting and you'll want to keep going! I'm afraid this game is so good that it's set the bar too high and I'm only disappointing myself by playing other VNs that are more focused on being a dating sim and may lack  good narrative."

So in this game you pick the Route you want to go in the beginning of the game. Each Route leads to a different love intrest with an own unique storyline. Each Storyline plays in 30 ingame days, starting the first of August. As the title suggest your character suffers from amnesia and your ultimate goal, next to romance is to get all your memories back.

I won't go too much into the spoilery area, but the love intrests you have are of different character types: The cool guy, who has been your friend since childhood, the superstar, who gets all the girls but falls in love with you, The efficient logical nerd guy, who is a tad socially awkward and the protective big brother type yandere character. You can have many different endings on each on this character routes, from the bad endings, to the normal endings, to the good endings.

There also is one bonus love interest character, that you get if you finish all other routes with best ending.
I always want Otome game to translate in English. And now I got Amnesia!!\nSo good!!!

Seeing that Amnesia: Memories is actually my first Otome game I've purchased and picked up, I really wasn't expecting much. I've played games like the Persona series and Harvest Moon series where there are these type of dating sims, but usually those games focused more on other types of gameplay (RPG and farming sim), but this is my first time picking a otome dating sim game where the main point of the game is to go through a span of 30 days with a chosen character where each answer and choice determines if you will be able to truly unlock the memories you've lost through Amnesia.

I thought that after 1 or 2 routes, I would get bored, but I was wrong. I think the strong element that Amnesia: Memories has is its ability to make you continuously want to know what's going to happen next, if you picked the right choices and what the ending you will get. The plot for each 'world' you choose in order to retrieve your memories is determined by the character you interact with. Every route has its differences and you will see how your chosen character develops through the span of 30 days you are given to unlock your memories. I found myself doing my best to get to the bottom of each conflict in each route and when I successfully got through it and achieved the good ending of a route, I felt rewarded for my efforts. and when I got a bad ending, I'd be screeching at my computer wondering what the heck I did wrong. I never thought I'd be invested so deeply in a game where all I literally do is click buttons.

Amnesia: memories caught my interest primarily because of its art. The CG images that are unlockable with each route and sprites are all so beautifully drawn. I also watched the anime that was revolved around this before I realized the game was coming out a week after I watched it. Watching the anime made me more curious about how the game would be and because of having that background, I was able to see how much more the game developed the characters and plot, something the anime could not (due to the amount of episodes).

The reason I am giving this game a 9/10 and not a full solid 10/10 is because I think that after I have completed and unlocked everything, the game has close to no replay value. I think that if there was additional content or gameplay, there would be a higher chance of this game keeping my interest in the long run if I ever wanted to pick it up and play it again. Unfortunately, after I complete everything, there's not much for me to go back to.  Since this is my first otome game, I'm not sure if that's how otome games are or if there's differences in each one in terms of mini-games and gameplay.

Nevertheless, I have been enjoying this game a lot. I am really happy that Amnesia: Memories was my first otome game. It left a lasting impression and I am eager to look into more otome games. I hope Idea Factory decides to localize the other games in the Amnesia series. I know I'd definitely be picking them up.

reviewText: Well done but not to my tastes. It's hard to identify with a player character when the demon in her head has more personality than she does.

Amnesia : Memories is a wonderful visual novel that I highly recommend. The basic premise is that you as the main character are suffering amnesia, as well as basically a spiritual possession, and are attempting to regain your memories  and free the spirit from your mind.

There are 5 total romanceable characters, all male.  The first 4 are available as soon as you start the game, the fifth one unlocks after finishing the good endings for the first 4 characters.  All of them have 1 good ending, 1 normal ending and between 1 and 7 bad endings.  They are all very well defined characters, with elaborate stories and very very different personalities.  You have a tsundere, a popular/playboy who yearns for real love, an intellectual who's aloof and bad with emotions and socializing, and 2 yandere characters that are on opposite ends of the yandere spectrum.  Each one of their stories take place on alternate dimensions, so even though the basic story premise is the same for each, the stories themselves are completely different and the side characters will sometimes have vastly different personalities in each route. As a fair warning, if you are someone who needs trigger warnings, you may have problems with one of the routes.

Getting the different endings requires making different selections during the story branches.  Each selection will either raise, lower, or leave your attributes in their current level of accumulation.  There is no stat raising or grinding, it's just a matter of selecting conversation options to raise or lower your trust, relationship and suspicion with each character.  There are quite a lot of branches, and it felt like there should have been more save slots available because of how many choices you have available.

The art is absolutely beautiful, the music and voice acting is great and fits in very well, the stories and characters are well written, and the translation is very accurate - though there are a very few spelling and grammar errors, it doesn't stick out horribly or detract from the experience.  After beating all the stories and endings there are also mini games, additional memories and short stories that follow up with the characters, leaving a huge amount of content in this game, it's really surprising how much content the game offers.

Pros:
+5 very different romanceable characters
+so many endings
+mini games
+unlockable bonus content
+art
+music
+story
+a 12 episode anime series you can watch elsewhere if the game isn't enough for you

Slightly Irritating:
~a few spelling/grammatical errors
~no obvious exit option in game
~while you can customize controls, it doesn't tell you what the buttons do
~for some people the achievements aren't working (IF is currently working on fixing it)
~a character who goes too far
~could use more save slots

Cons:
-I can't really think of anything outright negative about this game.  :)

If you like anime and/or visual novels I really recommend you pick up this game, it is definitely worth the money, even at full price!

Amnesia: memories caught my interest primarily because of its art. The CG images that are unlockable with each route and sprites are all so beautifully drawn. I also watched the anime that was revolved around this before I realized the game was coming out a week after I watched it. Watching the anime made me more curious about how the game would be and because of having that background, I was able to see how much more the game developed the characters and plot, something the anime could not (due to the amount of episodes).

The reason I am giving this game a 9/10 and not a full solid 10/10 is because I think that after I have completed and unlocked everything, the game has close to no replay value. I think that if there was additional content or gameplay, there would be a higher chance of this game keeping my interest in the long run if I ever wanted to pick it up and play it again. Unfortunately, after I complete everything, there's not much for me to go back to.  Since this is my first otome game, I'm not sure if that's how otome games are or if there's differences in each one in terms of mini-games and gameplay.

Nevertheless, I have been enjoying this game a lot. I am really happy that Amnesia: Memories was my first otome game. It left a lasting impression and I am eager to look into more otome games. I hope Idea Factory decides to localize the other games in the Amnesia series. I know I'd definitely be picking them up.

TL;dr: For an otome, it is quite dark. So things get crazy pretty quick. You have many hours that you can put into the game, depending on how fast you read, it may vary. The characters are all unique in their own way, some more unexpected than others. The Art is very beautiful, followed along with very well chosen voice actors. The stories all can get you very involved and wanting more. Only bleh is some achievements suck and Orion constantly yappin'.

Recommend: To those who like Visual Novels, unique characters, romance, engaging stories, and pretty art.

-----------------------------------------------
Game: There are lots of hours that can be put into this game which is good when seeing the price on this game. You get also a lot of unlockable additional content which makes it more worthwhile.  Such as memories and short stories in the boys' perspectives. Oh and mini-games which are pretty fun if you aren't in the mood for reading. Good amount of save slots, but in the end, I was wishing for more for Ukyo ~ n ~  Also is great that you can choose how it is read. You can turn on and off the V.A.'s, put it on Auto, Speed through text, show text and previous text all together, etc... Made it definitely a good experience. AND to make things better, if you're trying to get a different ending and playing through again, if you speed through, it will stop and play if there is text that you have previously not read in your other playthroughs! And it will highlight which answers you've already inputed. No trying to remember now :3


Achievements: Some of these achievemnts are literally so annoying I just gave up -.- One is where you have to click the image multiple times just for the guy to say a couple things. Looked up where to click and it still does absolutely nothing.  Everyone, but Kent's, I have had difficulty getting one part of their picture to work, It is seriously the dumbest thing ever. >_> The others are easy to obtain.

Anime VS. Otome: I found out about the anime first then the otome. I'm happy I came across the otome because now I realize how BAD the anime is. The anime doesn't cover really anything, Like the first 5-10 mins of the boys' story in the otome, so it was nice to really get to delve into these boys stories way more than the anime ever did.  Only thing is I kind of liked in the anime that Orion wasn't there 24/7. The otome he just literally drove me bonkers @ n @

Art: The art is very beautiful and definitely draws you in.  Their character design is actually very well thought out and you see a bunch of tiny things that really bring everything together, Also with their personalities, it ties in with the design. They have different poses which are good as well. The only weird thing for me is how large some of their hands were... But the style and coloring is very pretty. The gallery has lots of pretty images that are saved from your specific route and you can even move around the picture and check out different areas of it. There was a lot of variety and ones you unlock just from completing certain acheivements. Though that stupid ctrl-left click thing for their hidden" message things were annoying. I'd click and it would end up going to the next image instead. I had an immensley hard time trying to get parts of an image to register. No matter how many times I clicked Toma's fist in the 2nd variation nothing happened

reviewText: If you are a fan of otome games this is a good one. Though not as good as Hakuoki which is by the same creaters, it still is a beautiful game. When I tried the anime I felt like it was missing something and that the game was probably better. I was right. I like that you can get different endings depending on your choices. Plus the art is gorgeous.

This game was even more than I could have hoped for. Not only were the bad endings BAD - something that I feel I was spoiled with by DMMD, man are those endings horrible - but the normal endings are sweet and heartfelt and the good endings are perfect for each of the boys. I loved everything about this game, from the voice acting to the art to the story itself. It was a very fun read and I definitely plan on reading through it all again sometime! And I really hope that the other games get translated at some point too, because I just NEED more of these characters (and that Orion route, please please PLEASE).

I bought this basically as soon as it came out because once I watched the anime
I was totally hooked. I was so disappointed when I heard the Visual Novel was only
in Japan and on hand-held games however once I heard it was coming to Steam it
was so exciting.

The game has many merits, It's not a short visual novel like most, you're going to get
quite a few hours out of it and you're pretty much expected to play it over and over again.

There's minigames and such which are really fun, I personally find Air Hockey THE BEST.
The AI in the minigame's aren't too shabby either, they're atually quite good.

Orion, a character, is EXTREMELY annoying. Or at least I personally find that Orion constantly
commenting on each and every action and scene can be quite misleading and agitating.

The Art Style is beautiful and really well done, so are the animations. With this game, comes
an extreme amount of wonderfully stylistic and unique sets of scenery and characters.

Most characters are pretty unique, some are a little meh but that's only because they have generic
personalities that all animes/mangas/visual novels contain to some extent.

Music helps the scenes and can sometimes be a little freaky, you'll find out why..

So yes, I recommend this game. I love playing it because it's the best when you want to just relax.

reviewText: Hmm, what's there not to like about this ? You play as a character who has no memories and the only thing you can remember is a bug-like thing who's just told you the tragic reality that, hey ! He's hogging up all the space that, was originally, intended for your memories ! On top of that, how can you say no to five attractive boys that you get to yourself ? Whether you be a guy or girl, I still suggest playing this game. Each character are developed in their own unique ways making you want to figure out why ? Why had you fallen in love with him ? And what else beside his attractive looks can be so gosh darn evil ? Filled with drama, feelings, tears, regrets, and loyalty, Amnesia is a roller coaster on it's own. Amnesia is a surprisingly good otome game and visual novel.  I went into the game figuring the game would be standard otome fare, but I was pleasantly surprised to see that it's actually very well written, supplemented with good art and sound.  Each of the routes had their own particular charms, which surprised me, and my own expectations of which routes I'd prefer turned out to be totally wrong due to the strength of the story and the characterizations.

Localization for the game is very good.  For me, poor localization, typos, and awkward phrasing completely breaks immersion for me in visual novels.  In Amnesia, I can't even remember any awkward phrases, and I found only two typos during my entire playthrough.

The game does suffer from situations where the protagonist's actions (or lack thereof) defy common sense, though the use of Orion, her onboarded spirit, actually does help.  Orion tends to embody a lot of the inner dialogue (and outrage) of the gamer, embodying sentiments such as how dare he say that!" that the protagonist unfortunately doesn't really ever act upon.  Amnesia also suffers from the common visual novel ailment where as the player it can be virtually impossible to know how to avoid bad ends.  There were thankfully less of these than in some other games I've played
date: but I did find it often frustrating how a single choice led to a bad end that the game gave me no reasonable clues to predict.  Similarly

Amnesia is what you'd expect it to be for a visual novel read and choose the dialog options to decide your fate. There are a total of 5  arcs that took me 4-5 hours to 100% complete. There are a total of 5 routes 1 which is unlockable after completing the first 4 routes. The routes each have their own individual story lines according to who your love interest will be. The majority of the routes have 1 good ending, 1 normal and 2 bad endings some easier to obtain than others.

My favorite routes listed in order would be Kent , Toma , Unlockable route , Shin and Ikki

Through out the game Heroin doesn't do much talking as orion the spirit who got stuck to you helps you regain your memories in each world in order for him to separate from you as explained in the introduction of each route.  He helps you as much as he is able which is mostly helping you in the very few ways he can since he isn't seen by other humans and can't touch any human objects.  The majority of the game orion is basically the narrator due to the Heroin doesn't speak much until she regains her memories the more she recovers the more she talks. This can be annoying in some routes but he generally grows on you in most of the arcs.

There's CG to collect, 2 Mini games based off of Shins route , unlockable  memories and some other extras to further the game telling the story of each love interest.

PROs
Interesting Arcs
Verity of guys to choose from
nice soundtrack
Beautiful art work
All your friends , love interests, side characters are fully voice acted  (very well I might add)
nice extras
plenty of CGs to collect
Mini Games you can play against some of the characters
Orion can be extremely comforting in some of the arcs (especially 2 in particular)

CONs
Orion can become annoying (I know in 1 arc I was extremely irritated with him in)
some of the achievements can be tedious to obtain
certain themes may make some people uncomfortable
lots of reading (if you dislike reading but well this is a visual novel so what did you expect?)

For once, there's actually a VN side character that I dislike/hate as much as Umbridge, and that's saying something, Rika, I'm looking at you. Especially in the majority of the routes.

General Overview: You play as an amnesiac heroine thrown into a world with established relationships. It's up to you, with the help of a spirit called Orion to navigate and try not to get yourself thrown into the explosions of Bad Ends.

If you're expecting full-on fluff and all, this VN won't be for you. There're some fluffy moments, mixed with slight comedy but otherwise you're on the mystery/thriller/emotional rollercoaster train. This VN explores some dark elements in terms of human nature, as well as the struggles between doing what feels right and what doesn't, whether to follow your heart or your mind.

All the routes differ from one another, but overall there's actually a hidden connection between all of them which makes it all the more fascinating.

So far I'm thoroughly enjoying it. The writing is interesting, though it can be a little slow-paced in a route or two but otherwise it's very well-written. Especially the Joker route. Thanks, Otomate, I totally needed multiple trips to the feels train...

Good endings completed...now the normal and bad ones...

Most memorable line as of far:

I don't think you can call it deception when the people you're dealing with are stupid." - Shin"

Amensia memories is a great otome game thanks to the beautiful art, developed characters, decent voice acting, and the good writing. But more importantly, this game really shines as a whole. A lot of visual novels try just go with the different routes being unconnected so that you get a different experience with each, but not too much of a whole story. Amensia memories is able to provide the unique experience of multiple, separate routes while all braiding back together into a beautiful story.

The characters are also incredibly well done. While it is true your boys have this tendency to monologue at you, I rarely found myself wanting to skip through it. Often, I would say man, I wish there was a route for the girls in this game just because they too are well done and I would love to see more of them.

The final detail that makes Amesia Memories unique is the story telling is refreshing because of one lovable spirit. Orion takes the role of the narrator, guide, and friend so while the protagonist is not entirely robbed of her own voice and personality, it puts her on the back burner from having to forcibly describe every scenario and feeling. Often, visual novels get into an awkward form of story telling where the protagonist fails at show
date: not tell" and painfully details every thought and feeling. Instead
recommended: we have Orion asking your opinion and formulating plans that show how the protagonist

reviewText: Hmm, what's there not to like about this ? You play as a character who has no memories and the only thing you can remember is a bug-like thing who's just told you the tragic reality that, hey ! He's hogging up all the space that, was originally, intended for your memories ! On top of that, how can you say no to five attractive boys that you get to yourself ? Come on !\n\nOn a serious note though, this game is filled with twisted people, stories, and lots of love but can also be super knife wrenching hurtful to the point of making you scream your throat out as to why it had to happen like that. Ever since I saw the anime series released, I've been waiting for the day to play this game and I totally don't regret spending a lot of time crying and screaming for each of the attractive boys. Whether you be a guy or girl, I still suggest playing this game. Each character are developed in their own unique ways making you want to figure out why ? Why had you fallen in love with him ? And what else beside his attractive looks can be so gosh darn evil ? Filled with drama, feelings, tears, regrets, and loyalty, Amnesia is a roller coaster on it's own. Not only is the art and music for the game breathe taking as it is, each individual boys you take on will be a the best memories to uncover. So don't be afraid to say no to one of them because who knows what dark secret you'll uncover from that ?

reviewText: Amnesia: Memories takes one basic plot thread and weaves four major narratives from a single concept into four compelling worlds to take you on an unexpected journey. Having a basic plot concept retold in four different ways with multiple endings gives this VN excellent replay value.\n\nI initially had no expectation because I had only played one visual novel prior to Amnesia. I'm glad I went in neutral because I was pleasantly surprised at what I got. While I've only conquered three endings so far, I plan on finishing more. It's rare for me to sit through one playthrough let alone multiple playthroughs of a story-rich, dialogue-heavy game. The creators of Amnesia have clearly done something right.

In the game, you need to figure out stuff about your past whilst not making it obvious that you have amnesia. Also you pursue a guy.

Essential Characters:

Orion

Shin

-YANDERE SATAN. DO NOT TRUST THIS â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ ;;

This is my favorite otome game released in English.  I just love how each story is so different and seeing how little things about the characters change in each route.  I also love how, aside from a very short introduction, there is no common route to skip through before getting to the actual character routes.  Each character has his own unique route, so when I restart, I am really restarting from the beginning.  It takes away the disjointedness that some other VNs suffer from where the game only feels complete the first time you played through it.  Another really cool feature is that when you clear a route, you can click certain spots on certain images in the gallery for that character to hear new voiced tidbits (and yes, they are subtitled).  It makes me feel like there is a little more to discover about some of the game's sweetest scenes.  If you are a fan of otome or just want to play a really great visual novel with a hint of suspense and mystery, buy this game!

What can I say? The best otome I've ever played. The graphics, the voiceovers and the plot is simply well-made and engaging. I played through all the playthroughs, and even unlocked Ukyo's path, in which everything started to make sense.\n
Ikki is probably the most perfectly kuudere stereotype I've ever seen. Shin is stereotypically tsundere. But Toma... Toma is a yandere little ****.

I spent most of my playing time praying for a pool scene where the hot anime boys would take their clothes off. I wasn't disappointed.

THAT BEING SAID... I do have some issues with this game.

1. I absolutely hate how passive the heroine is. She just lets all these guys tell her what to do and she doesn't even care. Unfortunately this is a trope that a player will see in almost any otome game they play. :(

2. IF you haven't played this game, which I'm assuming you haven't because you're reading reviews, DO NOT under ANY CIRCUMSTANCES play the DIAMOND WORLD first. DIAMOND WORLD. Make sure you remember DIAMOND WORLD. Fortunately I didn't play Diamond first but I can say that if you aren't into creepy boyfriends, Diamond World will most likely leave you with a terrible first impression and might even make you never want to play this game. I will always 100% recommend Clover World to start out with because in my experience it is the best and least aggrivating (still somewhat aggrivating however, due to the nature of the man the heroine dates in that world)  I could have a little bit of a bias though because I've always had a soft spot for the nerdy types <3

3. Orion. Most people love him. However, I found him to be a little annoying because he never stops talking.

4. This game does a really good job of making Ukyo freak you out. I have yet to play his story (I haven't unlocked it yet because I can't go back to *shudder* Diamond World to get the ending I need) but from what I hear his actions in the game are justified and he's really sweet.

All of these things aside, this is a really good game if you want a little bit of mystery mixed with a lot of hot anime boys. I really really liked this game, although it might not seem like it. The hot shirtless anime boy scene was totally worth the creepiness of Toma and Ukyo. The math part of Clover world almost makes me turn the game off and chuck my laptop (I really hate math yo) but Kent keeps me coming back er'rytime.

19000000/10 would touch Kent's butt again. And again. And Again... >.>

Okay so this game is not like Dandelion Wishes Brought To You where it's more of a game. Amnesia is all story, it's like reading a book narrated by Orion (who'll you'll meet in the game) and answering the questions that your heroine will face. Answering these questions is all there really is to do in this game besides read so if you don't like books i don't recommend buying this game. however if you love books like me than you'll love this book like me. the story is rich (if sometimes scary) and you'll be obsessed with finishing.

TL;dr: For an otome, it is quite dark. So things get crazy pretty quick. You have many hours that you can put into the game, depending on how fast you read, it may vary. The characters are all unique in their own way, some more unexpected than others. The Art is very beautiful, followed along with very well chosen voice actors. The stories all can get you very involved and wanting more. Only bleh is some achievements suck and Orion constantly yappin'.

Recommend: To those who like Visual Novels, unique characters, romance, engaging stories, and pretty art.

-----------------------------------------------
Game: There are lots of hours that can be put into this game which is good when seeing the price on this game. You get also a lot of unlockable additional content which makes it more worthwhile.  Such as memories and short stories in the boys' perspectives. Oh and mini-games which are pretty fun if you aren't in the mood for reading. Good amount of save slots, but in the end, I was wishing for more for Ukyo ~ n ~  Also is great that you can choose how it is read. You can turn on and off the V.A.'s, put it on Auto, Speed through text, show text and previous text all together, etc... Made it definitely a good experience. AND to make things better, if you're trying to get a different ending and playing through again, if you speed through, it will stop and play if there is text that you have previously not read in your other playthroughs! And it will highlight which answers you've already inputed. No trying to remember now :3


Achievements: Some of these achievemnts are literally so annoying I just gave up -.- One is where you have to click the image multiple times just for the guy to say a couple things. Looked up where to click and it still does absolutely nothing.  Everyone, but Kent's, I have had difficulty getting one part of their picture to work, It is seriously the dumbest thing ever. >_> The others are easy to obtain.

Anime VS. Otome: I found out about the anime first then the otome. I'm happy I came across the otome because now I realize how BAD the anime is. The anime doesn't cover really anything, Like the first 5-10 mins of the boys' story in the otome, so it was nice to really get to delve into these boys stories way more than the anime ever did.  Only thing is I kind of liked in the anime that Orion wasn't there 24/7. The otome he just literally drove me bonkers @ n @

Art: The art is very beautiful and definitely draws you in.  Their character design is actually very well thought out and you see a bunch of tiny things that really bring everything together, Also with their personalities, it ties in with the design. They have different poses which are good as well. The only weird thing for me is how large some of their hands were... But the style and coloring is very pretty. The gallery has lots of pretty images that are saved from your specific route and you can even move around the picture and check out different areas of it. There was a lot of variety and ones you unlock just from completing certain acheivements. Though that stupid ctrl-left click thing for their hidden" message things were annoying. I'd click and it would end up going to the next image instead. I had an immensley hard time trying to get parts of an image to register. No matter how many times I clicked Toma's fist in the 2nd variation nothing happened

Visual Novels have always been a guilty pleasure of mine, taken in a large concentrated dose and then forgotten for months on end before the itch ever resurfaces. Usually I'm pretty satisfied when I drop the VNs that I've been working on regardless of completion status, but it's a first this time that not only have I completed Amnesia within 20-25 hours across the span of two short days but that I still want more.

Five paths. All unique. All satisfying. I loved how the characters tied back into each other across parallel worlds, picking each subsequent playthrough based on the character that intrigued me the most in the previous. Perhaps it was just a mark of how well things were done that I felt that with every playthrough I found out more and more about the overall storyline with no extraneous or repetitive revelations (so regardless of order, the sentiment would be the same) or that I somehow managed to pick the one best combination for optimal satisfaction: Ikki > Toma > Shin > Kent. The revelation about the girls at the end of Ikki's route really helped when I met them in subsequent routes. And Kent just ended off everything with the sweetest note.

Sinful voices. Gorgeous character art. Memorable personalities. And happily ever afters that I just want more of. Some of the paths are a little counterintuitive (to my personality) but there isn't really any choice that doesn't have plenty of clues laid out if you're paying attention. If I have one complaint is that there isn't more of the side characters; you do get more of them when you pursue Bad routes, but I'd have liked it more if the MC could've had both guy and friends, y'know? I felt awful about the lack of attention that Sawa got for the most of the game if you were trying for the Good ends; you needed to ignore her so many times!

Still. If you like VNs and you haven't played this game, please do. If you like anime, give it a shot since everything is fully voiced anyway, so you could technically just set it on autoplay, kick back and enjoy it. 10/10 would play again. Confession? I'm considering doing another run through of all the Good endings so I can end it on an Ultra high (since I had to work out all the Bad endings).

Amnesia: Memories is an otome game, meaning it's your goal as the protagonist to make it through the story alive and fall in love with your perfect anime husbando. Amnesia: Memories doesn't want you to make it through the story alive, so you have to work your butt off to not die while on the prowl for your big strong man.

Review

Sound: 10/10 -- Game is fully voice acted in Japanese with a beautiful backing soundtrack. I don't mind that it's repetitive in nature, it's a studio-quality soundtrack. Atmospheric and easy on the ears.

Art: 8/10 -- I personally enjoy the blurry, hand-drawn look of the backgrounds for each scene, but I know not everybody would agree. Also the outfits on the boys take me to the lawlacaust.

Story: 7.5/10 -- Overall the plotlines in each route are at least tolerable, though the protagonist can be incredibly frustrating and downright stupid. Holes in different places. Not Swiss Cheese holey, but still holey.

Boys: 7/10 -- For what we get to see of them, the boys whose emotions we get to know the most intimately are Shin's and Ikki's; both of these boys have powerful feelings that come through without them always having to say it. Toma and Ukyo both felt out-of-touch for me, because their characters were a bit outlandish. Toma felt far more troubled than he let on and Ukyo had lost his â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing marbles. I'd have liked to learn more about them. The most alive" of the boys

Amensia memories is a great otome game thanks to the beautiful art, developed characters, decent voice acting, and the good writing. But more importantly, this game really shines as a whole. A lot of visual novels try just go with the different routes being unconnected so that you get a different experience with each, but not too much of a whole story. Amensia memories is able to provide the unique experience of multiple, separate routes while all braiding back together into a beautiful story.

The characters are also incredibly well done. While it is true your boys have this tendency to monologue at you, I rarely found myself wanting to skip through it. Often, I would say man, I wish there was a route for the girls in this game just because they too are well done and I would love to see more of them.

The final detail that makes Amesia Memories unique is the story telling is refreshing because of one lovable spirit. Orion takes the role of the narrator, guide, and friend so while the protagonist is not entirely robbed of her own voice and personality, it puts her on the back burner from having to forcibly describe every scenario and feeling. Often, visual novels get into an awkward form of story telling where the protagonist fails at show

Amnesia: Memories is a visual novel that combines beautiful art with some of the best storytelling I've seen in a game in a long time. Do not confuse it with a Horror game of nearly the same name, because rather than leave you fearful, this title has the potential to leave you with a tremendous sense of awe, and almost sadness; not that the story is sad, but that it is over and you will never again experience it as you did that first time.

I 100%â€™d this game, something I almost never do, simply because I HAD to see all the endings, and the thought of being done with this game was more than I could handle. It is voiced (a big plus vs. other otomes) and keeps the story moving without burdening you with excessive side jobs to grind likeability stats.

I'll attempt to keep this as spoiler free as possible, but if you don't want to risk it, I will say this: get this game. This is the first game I have purchased where I wish I had spent MORE on it. I got this game on sale for $7, and I've seen it go under $5. It is worth full price. If you see it on sale, do not hesitate, grab it. This is a beautiful, smart and joyful game any visual novel fan should experience. Use one of the guides, I recommend Pie-inatorâ€™s, to help you get to each of the endings and enjoy.

Possible Spoilers Below

Amensia: Memories is about a girl who loses her memory when as stray spirit collides with her head. Whoops. Now, instead of any sense of self, she has a friendly little guide by the name of Orion to help her get through life and figure out who she is, and who she can trust. After a brief introduction to Orion, youâ€™ll pick your world, meaning, pick your guy.

The first choice is Shin. Shinâ€™s path is a good mystery. Heâ€™s a pretty typical tsundere, and your childhood friend. His best quality is that he understands the MC and will do absolutely anything to help and protect her. This pathâ€™s main function is to introduce you to the cast of characters that will play important roles as you continue your journey to understand the truth about this world you have stepped into.

Next up is Toma. If you didnâ€™t think there is a little something wrong, and dark, about your situation while playing Shinâ€™s path, you will understand it now. Tomaâ€™s path is not overly unique for otomeâ€™s and visual novels, but itâ€™s pretty twisted. Orionâ€™s interaction with your character takes it to the next level, especially if youâ€™re going for the happy ending. Itâ€™s pretty great making bizarre choices in a game and having someone actually call you out on it.

Next up is Ikki, a playboy type who you think you have all figured out the moment you meet him. But this is the path where you begin to realize this world has some really strange things going on, far beyond the normal. Ikkiâ€™s path is very sweet and really turns all of your assumptions about the character around. By the end, youâ€™ll probably have a little crush on Ikki, and thatâ€™s ok.

The forth path is Kent, a character who has mostly sat in the background in the previous paths. He is quiet and intelligent, and a bit harsh. As you begin this path, both you, Orion, and the MC wonder how it is that you are actually dating this guy. Your relationship is pretty rocky, to say the least. But the further you go down this path, the more and more Kentâ€™s true character comes out. This is probably the most romantic path, and ends in such a sweet way that you may find yourself falling for this adorable nerd.

Along the way, as mentioned, youâ€™ll also be interacting with Orion. His presence up until this point is pretty much a mystery, though if youâ€™ve been paying attention youâ€™ve started to get some clues as to whatâ€™s going on. His company really elevates the entire experience so far through his adorable reactions and unwavering support of the MC.

If youâ€™ve gone this far, you have also met the strangest character in the cast, Ukyo, and buckle up, because now that youâ€™ve completed the other four guysâ€™ paths, Ukyoâ€™s is now available to you. This is where the story goes from strong to unreal. Ukyoâ€™s path is the story of the world, the overarching plot that ties all other paths together and explains exactly what happened to the MC. It is heartbreaking and beautiful and very well may have you in tears by the end. Not to mention Ukyoâ€™s path has a grand total of NINE different endings.

Walking the path with Ukyo is dangerous and confusing, but leads to one of the biggest payoffs I have ever experienced in a game. It takes some time to get to this path, but to not experience this path is to not experience the game.
Overall this game is breathtaking, with beautiful art, fantastic music and an out of this world story. It is a SMART story, and doesnâ€™t talk down to the player, but rather challenges you to accept unbelievable circumstances as truths. It is not your typical otome. There is a depth to this world that you would expect out of a big triple-A RPG, not a casual visual novel. It is a must have for any visual novel fan.

Amnesia is a fantastic mystery-oriented, somewhat dark romance dating sim. You play as a heroine who wakes up with amnesia and you must try to hide your amnesia. This concept works really well because you as the player don't have any idea what's going on with the heroine's life. All the characters have their own charm and they're not stereotypical or flat. The UI is super smooth, the art is gorgeous, the music suits the mood and doesn't get too repetitive, and the voice acting...-it's really good. I got this game on sale and I felt like it was a great catch. This game made me question my choices and I actually learned a bit more about myself and how I would react in certain touchy situations.

I haven't completely fallen for any character yet (mostly because I'm most looking forward to Ukyo's route, haha).

Some minor complaints I have is that some scenarios aren't really consistent. It seems like only the good end route is the route that's completely consistent, while in the other routes the game seems to forget some details based on the choices you make. I also am not too fond of rereading the same text 4 times to get all the endings since there isn't too much variation in the story except for the end, but most VNs are like that. It also bothers me that the lip flap movements don't sync up with the voice acting, especially when the speech is being dragged out (I'm looking at you, Toma's seiyuu), but it's easy to ignore if you're reading the text most of the time. I really love the character art, but when the characters look surprised, they actually look like they're terrified...but these are all pretty minor flaws.

Overall, this game is fantastic and I would definitely recommend playing if you're into dark romance dating sims!
